displayed_text: Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and… Doctor: That’s what I’m thinking. Family Member: The tests should be back by then? Doctor: Yeah, but you know what just for now wait for a phone call and I’ll have S call you as soon as we get the results so we can sort of plan better for that Friday. Family Member: So it’s just a one day in and out thing? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Show me how is the shoulder doing? Patient: Oh the shoulders are good. Doctor: Okay what is…? Patient: I don’t have any you know… Doctor: Is this ten mg? Patient: Five in the morning, five at night. Doctor: Okay did it flare up after the treatment last time? Family Member: No.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And it’s a diagnosis you’ll carry and you’re we don’t - not really out of the woods for five or ten years. Family Member: And then when you say not cured, if the cancer will come back would those people be considered to be in remission? Doctor: So if, so when we get his PSA undetectable and finished therapy, he’s in remission. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Even so on the hormones. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Uhm and you’re in remission unless it recurs, comes back. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Last question, or uh maybe not. Mistletoe. I’ve had some friends that have said maybe that can help with side effects, things of that nature. If I were to research that, would that in any way – Doctor: Yeah, well thanks for asking that, so mistletoe is contraindicated certainly during chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it interferes with chem. I would say also during radiation.

Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I thought you’d like that. Downside if you have to be here all the time. It’s three times a week. Can you imagine vitamin C flitters outta your system. Patient: It does. Doctor: So this is a J___ study that we’re hoping to open within the next… Doctor: …Yeah, probably within the next month. Patient: Neither one of you know what the term ‘really old’ means. Doctor: That’s true. That’s true. Patient: Thank you. (laughs) Doctor: Um but that’s an option where… Patient: I’m working on year seventy-four so I’m hanging in there. Doctor: Doing pretty darn good. Um but I think the the downside of that trial is you’re here all the time, but the plus side is you’re getting you know the chemo is a standard and the vitamin C we’ll see what happens so. Patient: Yeah. If I need to cancel that trip… Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But after, the first year, every three months and then after that two to five years every six months, and then after that if everything stays okay then once a year. Patient: Because I take this serious. Doctor: Okay I can see that. Patient: I take this very, very, very serious. Doctor: The whole thing and I’m glad. Patient: You know I’m not trying to underestimate anything you know and you know because I never felt you know from the beginning I never felt… Doctor: Felt any symptoms. Patient: Yes. You know. Doctor: I understand. Neither did I. So we’ll get you to see Dr. R____ as soon as possible and I’ll see you back in three months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you get your blood test before you come back.

Patient: I can give you his contact information. Doctor: Yeah, I mean he’s at B___, right? Is it at B___ – L__ at B___? Patient: I think he’s at B___ or some other. Yeah, I’m not getting the radiation. Doctor: Is he T____? Patient: No, I might have some contact information. Doctor: Uh, okay it’s like K_ (spells name) Patient: S__ (spells name) Doctor: K__ (spells name) Patient: Let me just see what I have here for his. Doctor: Uh, and that’s what – February twelfth? Patient: That’s the first date of radiation. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: No, she’s, she’s asking why wouldn’t people want to know. Doctor: Some people don’t want to know. Because now it’s an anxiety you gotta live with, and you know, it doesn’t necessarily mean one-hundred percent, but if you have it, it’s a very high chance that, particularly for breast cancer, you could get breast cancer. So. Patient: My, my children? Doctor: Your children. Patient: And my grandchildren? Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Everybody. Family Member: Not me, but yeah, them. Doctor: Right. Everybody that, so, you have one, it’s, it’s a mutation in the gene. You have two copies of the gene. It’s, you know, so there’s a one and four chance you could pass it on because two copies come from your, their mother, and so, the mother contributes one, you contribute one. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: There’s a fifty/fifty chance, you could contribute a good one or bad one, so they -- you know – does that make sense? Patient: Right. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah I know all of that.

Family Member: Well he’s been pretty active. Patient: No, I’ve been pretty active. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He’ll fall asleep on a dime, but so do I. Doctor: Me, too. Now I wish I had a clinical study to offer you at this point, but our Xofigo plus something requires your disease to actually be worse than it is (not that I’m wishing you were on that) Patient: Right. Doctor: so at this moment. One, stop Xtandi; two, we’re going to give you some Xofigo paperwork and you’re going to do some of the – just give him some of the - Healthcare Professional: Lupron. Doctor: Lupron. And then we’ll send you on to see Dr. ___ for a consult. All of that is not a huge rush, but we’re just gonna move it along. Family Member: Yeah, because we’re leaving February fifth, so. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: So.

Patient: Is that the one that took the… Doctor: You had K____ Patient: K__ left. Doctor: but K____ left me so J____ is now working with me but actually J____ and I have worked together in the fifteen years I’ve been here. So, she was my original nurse that did a whole bunch of stuff but she’s always stayed on this team so she is also a very you know excellent prostate expert so she is going to help with trying to figure out if your insurance will say yes because it’s all great that you and I agree but if your insurance says, what are you kidding me, then we have to take that option off the table and just move on. Sound okay? Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: It’s kind of a lot today isn’t it? Patient: I want the best of what the best is for. Doctor: Yeah, No, I know. Patient: you know. Doctor: Well, but you’re a guy that doesn’t you know sit around. I mean part of the thing that we wanted to do earlier this year was just like knock out what you can knock out which you did. So, I’m sorry that we’re at this point but let’s not be sorry, let’s just do something about it. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so, are you due for a shot today? Patient: I don’t know. The last one I had was in June.

Patient: About my voice. All right. Huh, I . Do you think that’ll help? Doctor: Huh, like liquid-? Patient: So it’s not sore. Doctor: Like liquid saliva? Patient: No. That huh, what do they call it? Kaopec something. It’s chlo, chlo, chlo. Doctor: Chloraseptic? Patient: Yeah. Chloraseptic. Doctor: That might help. Or when you’re at the drugstore picking up your ibuprofen, there’s liquid saliva. Okay? So like you have the liquid tears. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: There’s artificial saliva. So that if this side of your mouth isn’t making the saliva, you can put some of that in, and just moisten it up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Because again, you are sort of, your tongue’s sort of moving over, but your brain looks good.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Hum. So they’ll radiate? Doctor: Uhn-uhn. This stuff that’s liquid goes everywhere in the bone. Family Member: Ohh! Doctor: So it isn’t like he stands there and they only shoot it up like a bone injection. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Uhn-uhn. You get an intravenous you know little catheter. Patient: And that’s going to be in me for six months. Doctor: Yeah, like they give it to you - it’s like one minute, and you’re done for the month. Family Member: Does he have to keep that catheter in there for the whole month? Doctor: No. Family Member: Oh good. Doctor: Like you put it in (makes mimicking sound) Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking.

Patient: Well, I don’t think it was so much carrying boxes because my kids and my wife wouldn’t let me carry weight. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But you did. Patient: But it was, no but it was never a heavy weight. It was just, yeah, I did do a lot of up and down the stairs. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Steps. Patient: And I noticed you know like the first day that Doctor: Right. Family Member: Could that trigger? Doctor: Of course. Hey my other guy, you know what he did? He wasn’t going up and down the stairs. He was just working under the tree putting his little village together. Up and down, up and down; he’s got the same symptom as you. So I think – Patient: So this isn’t something that if I give it total rest for - Doctor: Oh I’m sure that it will get better if you give it total rest. But it doesn’t change this discussion that I see new areas of cancer in your bone. Whether that’s causing pain is slightly different because I’m assuming it may. But it could be worsened because you were just moving. Family Member: Hum. So they’ll radiate?

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The other potential side effects, there is a small chance of dropping the blood counts, which is something we will be monitoring. If you have a fever, though, temperature one oh one or higher – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - I need to know about it right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: If you have diarrhea. If you have nausea. Anything out of the ordinary. You know? Skin rash. Things like that- Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: are possible side effects of these medications. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But those are things that you cannot just sit at home and wait until your next appointment and you elicit- Family Member: I don’t know who to call. I’m a registered nurse. Doctor: I know.

Patient: Thursday afternoon. Doctor: -a few days. that work out well for you Because… Patient: Thursday afternoon. We’re going to Canada on Saturday morning. Doctor: Okay and then next week. Patient: Closer than Vancouver. Doctor: Fair enough. Next week anytime? Family Member: For the same thing? Patient: Are we giving you a couple alternatives? Doctor: Yeah give me a couple options. Patient: Thursday this week and uh… Family Member: Monday? Patient: No No Tuesday next week. Doctor: Tuesday, good. That works out because then Tuesday I’ll be there too if you have any questions about the consent if anything comes up. So we’ll try for this week Thursday or Tuesday next week.

Patient: Positive as in good news? Or – Doctor: No, that you’ve got a mutation. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, so, it’s kinda letting the genie out of the bottle a little bit once I tell you the results. Because, it has, you know, significance for your family. Family Member: And that’s what I was going to ask you. Patient: Hey! I want to know. Doctor: Okay. So, there’s a gene called BRCA2 which is – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Associated with prostate and breast cancer. I’ll write it down for you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Um, that your – you have a mutation that you’ve inherited. What does that mean? Um. Well, we know that BRCA2 can be, um, a predisposition to getting prostate cancer. Patient: Well, I should tell you that -- I think it happened since I saw you – my brother was diagnosed.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, lovastatin forty milligrams a day Patient: Mm, hmm Doctor: The probiotic once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Your calcium with vitamin D one a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Cranberry extract, uh, twice a day. Patient: Uh, once a day; I dropped it back to once. Doctor: And the B12 once a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your Xgeva every month?
